qas.question: What is the Tuvalu high chief on each island called?
What is the name of the sub-chiefs in Tuvalu?
What is the Tuvaluan traditional assembly of elders?
What was the caste of priests in the past on Tuvalu?
With what group do the falekaupule share power on Tuvalu?

context: Each island has its own high-chief, or <a0_0>ulu-aliki<a0_0/>, and several sub-chiefs (<a1_0>alikis<a1_0/>). The community council is the <a2_0>Falekaupule<a2_0/> (the traditional assembly of elders) or te sina o fenua (literally: "grey-hairs of the land"). In the past, another caste, the priests (<a3_0>tofuga<a3_0/>), were also amongst the decision-makers. The ulu-aliki and aliki exercise informal authority at the local level. Ulu-aliki are always chosen based on ancestry. Under the Falekaupule Act (1997), the powers and functions of the Falekaupule are now shared with the <a4_0>pule o kaupule<a4_0/> (elected village presidents; one on each atoll).
